header_summary:
Russell O'Connor introduces BIP-93, codenamed codex32, a protocol that balances human and computer-generated randomness for enhanced security in secret sharing, demonstrating its relevance to cryptocurrency technologies and their evolution within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List. This innovation supports diverse applications, emphasizing the protocol's flexibility and broad utility, with more details available at [secretcodex32.com](https://secretcodex32.com/). 

In another development, an algorithmic enhancement within Bitcoin Core, detailed by an author known as sipa, addresses the challenge of partitioning equal-feerate transactions for improved fee rate management. Utilizing slight perturbations in transactions' fee rates, this solution facilitates efficient transaction grouping without altering actual fee rates, significantly refining Bitcoin Core's transaction processing capabilities. This advancement is documented in [Bitcoin Core PR #32545](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32545).

Brh28 raises concerns about the balance between privacy and performance in the Lightning network, critiquing proposals for forwarding delays due to potential exacerbation of performance issues. An alternative solution suggests introducing delays at the source and destination, offering a user-opted balance between privacy and efficiency without necessitating protocol changes, as discussed at [delvingbitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/latency-and-privacy-in-lightning/1723/2).

Lastly, 1440000bytes delves into the debate over the use of covenants versus multisignature arrangements in blockchain transactions. Emphasizing the experimental enthusiasm for covenant technology, the discussion highlights the necessity for critical evaluation of its unique advantages over multisig solutions, citing several proof of concepts that explore covenant applications in the blockchain sphere. This conversation can be explored further at [delvingbitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/on-the-possibility-of-evil-covenants-and-implications-for-soft-fork-proposals/1703/6).

- A solution for partitioning equal-feerate transactions in Bitcoin Core has been developed.

recent_posts.title: Latency and Privacy in Lightning
recent_posts.summary:
- Enhancing privacy in the Lightning network risks performance due to proposed forwarding delays.
- Proposed delays risk increasing payment failure rates and liquidity issues due to routing challenges.
- An alternative solution suggests applying delays at source and destination to balance privacy and performance.

recent_posts.summary:

- Interest in covenant technology is growing, as shown by numerous proof of concepts in blockchain innovation.

active_posts.title: Relax OP_RETURN standardness restrictions
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's standardness rules aim to mitigate DoS attacks, facilitate upgrades, and curb unwanted practices.
- Creative workarounds like the Citrea bridge's use of Taproot outputs show efforts to bypass data storage restrictions.
- Proposals suggest relaxing these rules by eliminating OP_RETURN output size and quantity limits to prevent promoting harmful practices.

active_posts.title: Unbreaking testnet4
active_posts.summary:
- Testnet4 was introduced to improve upon Testnet3 but kept a problematic difficulty reset rule.
- A proposed solution is to remove this rule via a flag day hard fork on January 1, 2026.
- The goal is to better simulate the Bitcoin mainnet while easing development on personal devices.

active_posts.title: jpeg resistance of various post-quantum signature schemes
active_posts.summary:
- Jpeg resistance describes a signature scheme's defense against specific attack vectors.
- RFC 8391 XMSS enhances security by including the public key in the message's hash.
- Techniques like Falcon's manipulation of signature components show varying jpeg resistance levels.

active_posts.title: How to linearize your cluster
active_posts.summary:
- Optimizing transaction clusters is crucial for processing in cryptocurrency networks.
- Advanced algorithms improve efficiency by sorting transactions and targeting bottlenecks.
- The current implementation benefits from these strategies despite some theoretical divergences.

active_posts.title: Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal introduces age-based expiration for dust outputs to combat UTXO set spam.
- Since 2023, the UTXO set size has doubled due to spam, reaching 11 GB.
- The solution could make small, old outputs unspendable, reducing UTXO set clutter.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:
- The study examines compact block reconstructions in Bitcoin, focusing on transaction pre-fills and additional requests.
- Adjustments in node configurations, like increased connections or changes in mempool policies, impact reconstruction efficiency.
- Observations suggest that enabling `mempoolfullrbf` by default could significantly improve block reconstruction times.

today_in_history_posts.title: Congestion Control via OP_CHECKOUTPUTSHASHVERIFY proposal
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Jeremy Rubin proposed a new opcode, OP_CHECKOUTPUTSHASHVERIFY, for Bitcoin congestion control.
- The opcode allows trustless, improved payment confirmations to many users without immediate UTXO creation.
- Its deployment with Taproot as OPSUCCESS or separately, along with a reference implementation, is discussed.

today_in_history_posts.title: BOLT #3: Shouldn't timeout be included in the script of "Offered HTLC Outputs" for the local node?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The author questions the BOLT #3 documentation on HTLC script details.
- They highlight a potential oversight in not timelocking the local node's output.
- The author seeks clarification on the script's handling of timelock expiry.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability aims for 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" to support 1 billion users.
- Innovations like coinpools and federated sidechains are pivotal for transaction cost efficiency and scalability.
- Future development focuses on enhancing security, regulatory compliance, and maintaining Bitcoin's core values amidst scalability efforts.
